text:
I clicked on the link to see how much these are going to cost, since as of right now it is only a pre-order. There were a lot of ways to contact them to have them get back to you, but no way to actually find out the price without them having your contact info and being able to possibly spam you with sales calls. Maybe I'm the only one, but that makes this a non-starter for me. I used to teach laser cutting at a maker space on a $75,000 laser cutter (I did not own it), so I know they can get up there, and I'm sure this one is no where near that. But, I'm not going to jump through hoops to find out.

Some people will say, "Well, if you have to ask, you can't afford it." Except that if you are a small shop, and have a budget, it is actually possible that you could afford it, and you would like to know so you can set aside the money,.......   

It's more like, "If your potential customer has to ask, then you probably shouldn't be hiding it."
video: This is the World's Fastest Laser

text:
Thank you for tackling what could be a thorny subject. Personally I always love to listen to reviewers' takes on the machines and I usually form some opinion using an aggregate of reviews. And even this only forms part of my overall opinion. Reviews are great but they never take the place of doing your own hard research. And you have to accept that MOST of these lasers are built in part or in whole in China where the quality is not always consistent. So no matter what you do you may end up with a bad sample of an otherwise good laser. I am much more concerned about the company I am buying from and their customer service than the actual laser itself 99% of the time.

But that being said I do thing the reviews have value as long as nobody doing them tries to hide the fact that they received the laser for free for review. Honesty and openness are the requirement for these reviews to have any merit. You have never given me any reason to think you are otherwise so I love following your channel.
video: Can You Trust Product Reviews?

text: P2 (still in the box while we wait for our new house to be finished), Glowforge (good comparison?) and the F1
video: Can You Trust Product Reviews?

text: I bought an Orion Motor Tech (omtech) 50w a few years back and it has never worked right from day one, had a bad tube they refused to replace, i requested a discount on a new one and they refused also, many of the screws were not tapped right or stripped, power supply died, the controller has intermittent issues, honestly it was a complete lemon and the "warranty" was useless.
video: Can You Trust Product Reviews?

text: I watch you regularly, and expected that your knowledge level would be a bit higher. First, she talks about the speed. Owning an Epilog Fusion Pro, I know something about speed. At top speed and max output power, you are hardly leaving a mark on wood. So, the speed argument is a little dumb. The accordions on the side of the gantry to protect the internals of the machine is something Epilog has had for years. The idea that somehow, the autofocus built-in to the lens carriage is something new is also wrong. Epilog, Trotec, and honestly several others I can think of have been doing that for years. Servo motors? Welcome to 2020. Let's talk resolution. 1000 DPI, is nowhere near class-leading. She talks about how happy she is about how rigid they are, being built of steel. Why did they add several hundred pounds to the machine by cheapening out with steel when they should have gone with military grade aluminum. I notice that my Epilog is under 300 pounds while the Aeon with the same bed size is 550 pounds. Some of them go up to 1,500 pounds. She talks about being able to change frequency, well I am not certain, but I think several companies have had that for years. I know I can change that on mine. The drop-in water cooled tube that doesn't change alignment is cool, bravo on that point! Even if you could buy one, (many people can not get a regular Mira for months) some interviews have said their Signature series (the only one that can boast all of this speed and ceramic RF core) is not even on the horizon for 4 to 6 months. Last thing is price. Who in the name of all that is holy is going to pay Epilog prices for a Chinese machine? I think it is just a reverse engineered Epilog or Trotec. There was a time when I would have looked at an Aeon or Thunder, but they were just too slow for my production needs. And please, add an LCD screen! What a strange place to try to save a buck, the one thing you will touch EVERY SINGLE TIME YOU USE THE LASER!
video: This is the World's Fastest Laser

Curved surface engraving doesn't actually require a camera.
Batch processing is useless, even in the demo you had to adjust positions which defeats the purpose. Certainly not good enough for production use unless your clients don't mind sloppily aligned engraving.

text: If you're looking for a lower-power diode laser (10W or less), and you already own a 3D printer, some companies (such as Creality) offer a bolt-on laser module for your specific model.  This way, you utilize the motorized axis control of the printer you've already spent your bucks on, and can get the laser unit for MUCH cheaper than a stand-alone laser cutter/engraver.

text:
Considering the xTool P2 for your laser cutting and engraving needs is a good idea, but I would also recommend exploring the Monport laser for its exceptional features and benefits. Here's why:

Ease of Use: While the xTool P2 may offer some convenient features, the Monport laser is renowned for its user-friendly interface and straightforward operation. Whether you're a beginner or an experienced user, you'll find the Monport laser easy to set up and use for your projects.

High Quality: The Monport laser is known for its high-quality engraving and cutting capabilities. It delivers precise and detailed results on various materials, ensuring that your projects come out beautifully every time.

Affordability: Despite its high quality, the Monport laser is affordable, making it a cost-effective option for hobbyists, small businesses, and professionals alike. You'll get excellent value for your money with the Monport laser.

Overall, while the xTool P2 may have some appealing features, the Monport laser offers a compelling combination of ease of use, high quality, affordability, versatility, and reliability. Be sure to check out the Monport laser product page for more information and to see how it can enhance your laser cutting and engraving experience. https://monportlaser.com/collections/co2-laser-engravers/products/monport-40w-lightburn-ready-12-x-8-co2-laser-engraver-cutter-with-fda-approval?sca_ref=5031521.ka374VZjm3

text: I own the F2P as well and I'm a bit saddened by the inability to raise the z-height on this unit, despite being promoted on Creality's own listing page. I suggest anyone looking into this printer be VERY cautious. You're paying a lot of money for a supposedly versatile tool. If you think someday you might use a rotary tool on this thing -- you probably won't. The tray CANNOT be removed to extend the legs so you can fit a rotary. The device uses a magnetic switch to detect when it's removed, and shuts off the laser. So just be aware that you are basically buying a $300 CNC laser with a $20 lid on it and a PC case fan to vent it.
video: The Best Laser Engraver and Cutter to Get in 2024

The device uses a magnetic switch to detect when it's removed, and shuts off the laser. So just be aware that you are basically buying a $300 CNC laser with a $20 lid on it and a PC case fan to vent it.

text:
I've watched other comparisons where actual cutting time was measured. Before fully understanding the logic used to control the laser, I was surprised to see that machines with 600 to 1,000 mm speeds could only produce parts at roughly the same run time as machines with a maximum speed of 300 to 400 mm. The reason is that the faster machines have to overshoot the work area when ramping up and slowing down.

Ultimately, the best choice of laser comes down to (1) the purpose you intend to use it for (cutting or fine engraving) and (2) how fast it can perform the required task.

text:
Given that 30-40W will cut 15 mm plywood and ~20+mm wood/particleboard, once you get into/past that 30-40w range size starts to be become the more important metric for many/most. 

A 3-400mm square 70w laser will for most be a LOT less interesting than a 500mm+ square 40W model and available space becomes the real limitation.

I would buy a 600mm square 40W laser over a 300mm square 70w laser for a similar price and it wouldn't even be a difficult choice.....

text:
I don’t see how any of these strategies would work at all for somebody starting in 2024. Etsy is an absolute mess of sludge from drop shippers dumping junk from Temu, Ali Express. Every social media platform blocking any promotions for Etsy stores at every step of the process up to and including shadowbanning accounts and nerfing engagement entirely. This doesn’t even account for how much AI generated images have completely swarmed other store platforms to the point that it’s hard to tell what is a real storefront or just another grift. 

By all means prove me wrong, but the strategies that worked in 2017 from standstill are no longer effective today. Perhaps this video would be better suited for people who already have stores and just need a few tips, but then a few sections of this video wouldn’t be relevant to them (e.g. pricing etc)

text: Be advised that if you have purchase and receive a defective unit Longer has no customer support. I called and emailed after purchasing one of their units do to it having issues and not feeding any filament and PLA, TPU, PTGE and they will not respond. Furthermore they blocked my number from calling them as now it goes directly to voicemail but when I restrict my caller ID the phone rings before being directed to voicemail. I would avoid this company all together and picking an alternative option..

text: I have the 10 watt Roly.  I really like it.  It works great.  It was able to cut through 7mm cedar.  I have kids so I like that it is fully enclosed.  Using its wireless, the Roly can act as a web server.  I load designs onto a micro SD, make the Roly act as a web server and I use the browser on my phone to tell the Roly which file to cut.

Provided with BOM if not) and i still dont understand! Hard wood,not doing it for me! Regular wood? The fibers are going to burn and the contrast and shades are off. Recomandation! Flat soft wood,No fibres! Even! For portrait and face,use jarvis settings in Lightburn for good shades in Peisaje!

text:
No mention(not even on their site) of the maximum material thickness that can fit under the lens...

When you start getting into lasers with power suited for primarily cutting that matters as 30-40+ watt laser will work for 15mm plywood and 19-22mm particle-board flooring which opens a whole other world as far as the functional tools and jigs you can make with those materials...
